p: Naringenin (4′,5,7-trihydroxytlavanone) (Fig. 9) occurs naturally in a variety of citrus fruits, bergamot, tomatoes, tomato food products, grapefruit, sour orange, cherries, cocoa and it is may be found in some herbs such as oregano and water mint. Naringenin has many pharmacological effects, including antidiabetic, antiatherogenic, antidepressant, immunomodulatory, antitumor, antiinflammatory, DNA protective, hypolipidaemic, antioxidant, antiasthma, antiviral, antibacterial and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) activator [ 56, 104].
